channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: An Iranian American Was Arrested in Iran, U.S. Confirms
item.description: Rights groups said that Reza Valizadeh, an Iranian-American journalist, was recently arrested in Iran, although the State Department did not confirm that he was the person detained.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators mark the 45th anniversary of Iran’s takeover of the U.S. embassy in Tehran.

item.title: Trump or Harris Victories Offer Different Futures for Ukraine
item.description: The presidential candidates have expressed starkly contrasting visions for America’s role in the war, as well as the NATO alliance that serves as a shield against Russian aggression.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine firing a howitzer at Russian positions in June.

item.title: Sikh Activists See It as Freedom. India Calls It Terrorism.
item.description: Canadian and U.S. accusations of assassination plots have drawn attention to the Sikh separatist movement, which India calls a source of organized crime.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:credit: Jackie Dives for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khalistan flags last year in Surrey, British Columbia. India has repeatedly accused Khalistan-related activists in countries like Canada of sponsoring gang warfare, drug trafficking and extortion in India.

item.title: After Deadly Floods in Spain, Thousands of Volunteers Help in Recovery Effort
item.description: As the country reels from a flood that has left at least 214 people dead, thousands have flocked to devastated areas to help. Anger toward public officials is growing.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel, José Bautista and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Volunteers sweep the mud from a street in the aftermath of the flooding, in Alfafar, near Valencia, Spain on Saturday.

item.title: Polish Radio Station Uses A.I. to Interview Dead Nobel Laureate
item.description: A radio station in Poland fired its on-air talent and brought in A.I.-generated presenters. An outcry over a purported chat with a Nobel laureate quickly ended that experiment.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mariusz Marcin Pulit, who runs Radio Krakow and niche stations operating under its umbrella like Off Radio Krakow, said his only goal with the experiment was to revive a station that had few listeners.

item.title: A Lebanese Town Tries to Stay Out of Israel-Hezbollah War
item.description: While Lebanese are united against Israel’s onslaught, some in southern towns where Hezbollah does not hold sway say they feel caught between Israel’s firepower and Hezbollah’s fighters.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and David Guttenfelder
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A boy, displaced from his family’s border village home, playing in the courtyard of the Kfeir public high school in Hasbayya province, Lebanon, last month.

item.title: Khamenei Threatens Israel With ‘Crushing Response’ to Attacks
item.description: His comments came as the Pentagon said it would send additional fighter jets and destroyers to the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sign in Tehran, Iran, reads “Another storm is coming” in Hebrew and Persian. Some Iranian officials have said their country would retaliate for Israel’s Oct. 26 strikes on Iran.

item.title: Israel Says Elite Naval Commandos Abducted Hezbollah Operative
item.description: It appeared to be the deepest Israeli operation by sea and ground inside Lebanon during the current war.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Aaron Boxerman and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Lebanese soldiers on Saturday inspect the site where Israeli naval commandos are believed to have landed to abduct what Israel said was a Hezbollah operative in the coastal city of Batroun in northern Lebanon.

item.title: German Government at Risk of Collapse After Rift on Economy
item.description: A breakup of the divided and unpopular coalition well before elections set for next September could leave the country directionless at a critical time for Europe.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The three key leaders of Germany’s coalition government, from left, Robert Habeck of the Greens, the economic minister; Chancellor Olaf Scholz of the Social Democrats; and Christian Lindner of the Free Democratic Party, the finance minister, in September.

item.title: Kemi Badenoch, New Leader of the U.K.’s Tories, Vows to Make the Party More Conservative
item.description: Ms. Badenoch is expected to move the party, now in the opposition, further to the right.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

item.title: Mexico Supreme Court Justice Seeks to Ease Political Tensions, but Obstacles Persist
item.description: A lone voice on Mexico’s Supreme Court has proposed a way to ease the political tensions that have arisen over a judicial overhaul. But big obstacles could prevent any deal.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juan Luis González Alcántara, a justice of Mexico’s Supreme Court, is proposing what he considers a compromise over a judicial plan that would overhaul how nearly all the country’s judges are selected.

item.title: Amid Flood Cleanup in Spain, Residents Try to Make Sense of the Disaster
item.description: Some see the floods as an example of the effect of a changing climate that is making overwhelming downpours more common. Locals also say government warnings came too late.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: A general view of the area affected by floods in Chiva, Spain, on Friday.

item.title: In Mexico, Archaeologists Spot a Maya City Behind a Wall of Trees
item.description: A city with temple pyramids not far from the road and a site with a Maya complex built alongside a sinkhole lend to evidence that the Maya civilization was even more sprawling than known.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Luke Auld-Thomas Et Al, via Reuters
item.media:description: In this lidar image released by Cambridge University Press, what archaeologists in Mexico say is a newly discovered lost Maya city, which they named Valeriana, is hidden deep in the southern jungle of Campeche, Mexico.

item.title: Pro-West Leader Wins High-Stakes Vote in Former Soviet Republic
item.description: The president of Moldova, Maia Sandu, won re-election on Sunday against a rival candidate she had denounced as “Moscow’s man.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Maia Sandu, who narrowly won re-election as Moldova’s president, celebrating the election runoff’s preliminary results in Moldova’s capital, Chisinau, on Sunday.

item.title: Monday Briefing: The Final Set of Times/Siena Election Polls
item.description: Plus, using generative A.I. to take a “decision holiday.”
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Doug Mills; Erin Schaff/The New York Times

item.title: Thousands of Children in Gaza Get 2nd Dose of Polio Vaccine
item.description: Aid agencies said that children in some areas of northern Gaza where Israel is mounting an offensive against Hamas will miss the doses, compromising the effectiveness of the campaign.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinian children arriving for their vaccinations at a hospital in Gaza City on Saturday.

item.title: COP16 Talks in Colombia Adopt a Novel Way to Pay for Conservation
item.description: Delegates at the U.N. talks created a system that would compensate countries for the use of genetic information but failed to make headway on a broader funding commitment.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: The talks, sponsored by the United Nations, were held in Cali, Colombia.

item.title: Taking Time
item.description: Daylight saving time ends tomorrow. How will you make use of the extra hour?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Abortion Rights Issue Surfaces in Canada Before U.S. Election
item.description: The Canadian government proposed legislation this week to crack down on anti-abortion organizations that provide “dishonest counseling” to pregnant women.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An anti-abortion rally on Parliament Hill in Ottawa in May.

item.title: Young African Voters Reject Liberation-Era Political Parties
item.description: Political parties that have governed for decades since African countries overthrew colonial rulers are now being challenged by frustrated young voters.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Yvonne Mooka
item.media:description: Supporters of the winning candidate for president in Botswana cheering on Thursday at a counting center in Gaborone, the capital.

item.title: Israel’s Peace Talks in Gaza and Lebanon: What to Know
item.description: Complex negotiations involving several players are proceeding on two separate but related tracks.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Smoke rises following an Israeli bombardment in Beit Lahia in the northern Gaza Strip on Friday.

item.title: Russia Showers Cash on Men Enlisting in Ukraine War, Bringing Prosperity to Some Towns
item.description: With fewer men willing to fight, Russia is focusing on cash incentives for those who sign up, seeking to avoid an unpopular draft while still increasing the ranks of soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva
item.media:description: A recruitment center for military service in St. Petersburg, Russia, in April.

item.title: Photos of Trench Warfare in Ukraine in the Age of Drones
item.description: At a critical battlefield in eastern Ukraine, advanced technology is shaping battles that resemble the wars of older eras. When drones are watching, assaults become violent sprints.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier repels a Russian attack with a rocket-propelled grenade outside Toretsk, Ukraine this month.

item.title: Can Iran and Israel Find a New Equilibrium?
item.description: Even with peace talks underway, the region is far from stable.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new billboard in Tehran with photos of President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on one side, labeled as “Warmongers,” and President Masoud Pezeshkian of Iran and a military officer, on the other side.

item.title: To Join This Club, a Member Must Die. And You Must Adore Verdi.
item.description: Based in Parma, Club dei 27 is so exclusive that it’s given rise to all sorts of myths. But it’s really about venerating the famous opera composer born near the Italian city.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Marco Gualazzini for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of Club dei 27 singing “Va Pensiero” in celebration of Giuseppe Verdi last month outside his birthplace near Parma, Italy.

item.title: Canadian Police Say They Dismantled Country’s Largest Drug Lab
item.description: Federal officers in British Columbia seized drugs and chemical precursors that could produce about 96 million opioid doses, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Darryl Dyck/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police in British Columbia seized what they said was a record number of illicit drugs during a recent raid.

item.title: How a Year of Rain Flooded Spain in Eight Hours
item.description: The region is no stranger to storms like those that caused this week’s deluges. But global warming helps them pack a bigger punch, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: A pileup of cars in Valencia, Spain, on Wednesday, after catastrophic rains.

item.title: Dublin Crowds Turn Up for Halloween Parade That Wasn’t
item.description: The scariest thing this Halloween? In one city, it was the power of a phony online event listing.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Victor Mather
item.media:description: People in Dublin awaiting floats and characters that would never arrive.

item.title: New Zealand Airport Puts Hugs on a Timer
item.description: The new rule at a New Zealand airport limits curbside embraces to three minutes, drawing worldwide commentary, from the indignant to the amused.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:credit: Sarah Soper/Dunedin Airport, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A sign informing travelers of the new rule in the passenger drop-off zone at Dunedin Airport in New Zealand, in October.

item.title: Israel Strikes Near Lebanon’s Capital as Hopes for a Cease-Fire Fade
item.description: The Biden administration sent envoys including the C.I.A. director to the Middle East this week, but Israel, Hezbollah and Hamas all appeared far from a deal to end the fighting.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: The aftermath of overnight Israeli airstrikes in Beirut’s southern suburbs, on Friday.

item.title: As Russia Advances, U.S. Fears Ukraine Has Entered a Grim Phase
item.description: Weapons supplies are no longer Ukraine’s main disadvantage, American military officials say.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, Helene Cooper and Kim Barker
item.media:description: Damage from a Russian bombing attack in Sloviansk, Ukraine, last month. Ukraine is losing territory in the east, and its forces inside Russia have been partially pushed back.

item.title: Rúben Amorim, Manchester United and the Burden of History
item.description: Winning at Manchester United will be tough enough for the club’s new manager. Unfair comparisons with the past won’t help.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Spain Braces for More Rain and Flooding as Rescuers Dig Through Debris
item.description: The authorities said dozens of people were still missing, as forecasters warned of new flooding in the southwest of the country.
item.dc:creator: José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: A woman clears mud off the street after heavy flooding in Paiporta, near Valencia, Spain, on Friday.

item.title: Destructive Israeli Raid in West Bank Kills 5, Palestinians Say
item.description: The Israeli military said its soldiers had engaged in close combat in the Nur Shams area of the occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Fatima AbdulKarim
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: The damaged headquarters of UNRWA, the U.N. agency that helps Palestinians, in the Nur Shams area of the Israeli-occupied West Bank, on Friday after an Israeli raid in the area.

item.title: As Famine Stalks Gaza, Farmers Lament Their Many Losses
item.description: After more than a year of war, farmers have lost land, equipment and sometimes their lives.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:description: Farmers inspecting the damage to a greenhouse after it was hit in a strike in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, in January.

item.title: How Wagner’s Ruthless Image Crumbled in Mali
item.description: The Russian mercenary group operated with little pushback in the West African nation — until it launched one of its most ambitious missions.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Triebert, Elian Peltier, Riley Mellen and Sanjana Varghese
item.media:credit: Coordination of Azawad Movements, via, via Reuters

item.title: Repression Intensifies in the Country Hosting a Major Climate Meeting
item.description: Human rights watchdogs say Azerbaijan is in the midst of a vicious campaign of repression. But in global geopolitics, this energy-rich Caucasus country now has a lot of leverage.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Azerbaijan will host the 29th United Nations Climate Change Conference, known as COP, in November in its capital city, Baku.

item.title: She Was the First Nicaraguan to Be Crowned Miss Universe. Can She Ever Go Home?
item.description: After Sheynnis Palacios won the Miss Universe title, her country’s government arrested the family members of the Miss Nicaragua contest director, and she hasn’t returned home since.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Kirsten Luce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheynnis Palacios, the first Nicaraguan to win the Miss Universe pageant, now lives in New York City as is customary for a year after winning the title.

item.title: Can Axions Save the Universe?
item.description: The hunt for dark matter is shifting from particles to waves named after a laundry detergent.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Katrina Miller

item.title: Botswana Voters Hand Governing Party a Stunning Rebuke
item.description: After 58 years, the Botswana Democratic Party lost its majority in Parliament, becoming the latest long-dominant party in southern Africa to fall from power.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Mooka and John Eligon
item.media:description: Botswana’s newly-elected President Duma Boko delivers his acceptance speech at the Mass Media Complex in Gaborone on Friday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Devastating floods in Spain.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Severe rain and flooding caused devastation in Paiporta, Spain.

item.title: In Spanish Town Devastated by Flood, a Grim Search for Bodies
item.description: Rescuers in Paiporta, where more than 60 people died, were still pulling bodies from the mud. “We are alive,” a resident said. “But we have lost everything.”
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Residents of Paiporta, Spain, a town on the outskirts of Valencia, trying to clean a flood-ravaged street on Thursday.

item.title: Mexico’s New President, Claudia Sheinbaum, Faces First Major Crisis
item.description: A confrontation between the judiciary and the governing party will test Claudia Sheinbaum’s leadership and offer a window into how she will wield power.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico in Congress last month, after her swearing-in. Her party’s overhaul of the Mexican judiciary “will be an example to the world,” she has said.

item.title: Trump Had an ‘America First’ Foreign Policy. But It Was a Breakdown in American Policymaking.
item.description: A second Donald J. Trump presidency would almost certainly mark a return to an era of foreign policy decrees, untethered to any policy process, at a moment of maximum international peril.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: As president, Donald J. Trump was never a true isolationist, in spite of his rhetoric.

item.title: Friday Briefing: The Global Stakes of the U.S. Election
item.description: Plus, Japan's passion for the World Series.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta

item.title: Iranian Officials Threaten Retaliation for Israeli Strikes
item.description: It was unclear how or when Iran plans to respond, or whether the rhetoric could be bluster. Iranian officials had downplayed the damage of Israel’s last attack.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Gen. Ali Fadavi, deputy chief of the Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps, on Thursday indicated that Iran intends to retaliate for Israel’s recent attacks.

item.title: Germany Shuts 3 Iranian Consulates Over Execution of German-Iranian
item.description: The rare step of closing the consulates reflected German protests over the execution of Jamshid Sharmahd, an outspoken opponent of the Iranian regime.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: The Iranian Embassy in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Turns to China to Stop North Korean Troops From Fighting for Russia
item.description: American agencies have assessed that China dislikes the growing partnership between Russia and North Korea. The State Department has raised the troop issue with Chinese diplomats.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, in a photograph released by the Chinese state media. China is North Korea’s longtime ally and its most powerful economic and military partner.

item.title: ‘Witches’ Marks’? Curses? Medieval Etchings Uncovered at Manor House
item.description: A discovery of etched symbols and writing at a British Manor House has experts examining their possible meaning.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Gainsborough Old Hall, where a “staggering array” of carved ritual protection or apotropaic marks were found, in Lincolnshire County, England.

item.title: Spain Flash Floods: Scenes From the Deluge
item.description: Flash flooding across Spain killed more than 150 people after torrential rain left towns and villages submerged and turned streets into rivers.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A flooded cemetery on the outskirts of Valencia, Spain, on Friday.

item.title: Strike on Gaza Hospital Destroys UN Supplies, Palestinian Officials Say
item.description: Israeli troops had withdrawn from Kamal Adwan Hospital after arresting most of the medical staff. The Israeli military said it was “unaware of a strike” there.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack
item.media:description: Wounded Palestinians being treated this week at Kamal Adwan Hospital in Jabaliya, in the northern Gaza Strip.

item.title: The World Series Was Big in Japan. The TV Ratings Prove It.
item.description: Shohei Ohtani, the Dodgers’ superstar, drove massive interest for the World Series in Japan, where more than 15 million people watched each of the first two games.
item.dc:creator: Hisako Ueno and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Richard A. Brooks/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dodgers fans cheering at a bar in Tokyo on Thursday.

item.title: U.S. Officials Try to Advance Israel’s Cease-Fire Talks With Hezbollah and Hamas
item.description: William Burns, the C.I.A. director, made a last-ditch attempt to move Gaza talks along before U.S. elections next week.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: People searching through rubble at the site of an Israeli strike in Beit Lahia, in the northern Gaza Strip, on Wednesday.

item.title: After Flash Floods in Spain, Rescuers and Residents Face a Grim Scene
item.description: Others are still missing, though how many remains unclear. Rescuers feared finding more bodies, the defense minister said.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola, José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Oscar Del Pozo/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: How the next U.S. administration may shape the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Bing Guan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Early voting is underway in many states.

item.title: In China, Comedy Is Giving Women a Voice. But Can Men Take a Joke?
item.description: Comedy has become a way for women to skewer China’s gender inequality. Some men aren’t happy about it.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
